Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Domain-Domain and Protein-Protein Interactions in Reactive Oxygen Species
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Chin-Chuan Wei from Southern Illinois University Edwardsville who is investigating an important class of proteins that have been implicated in disease processes such as atherosclerosis and tumor growth. The program involves studying how the functions of these proteins are ultimately related to their unique structures as governed by weak interactions between various proteins and other molecules. The Professor Wei is characterizing these weak interactions in an effort to understand the similarities and differences of these protein functions and to provide new insights in enzymology. The project participants, including undergraduate and M.S. graduate students, acquire specialized training in protein preparation and characterization techniques, that enhance fundamental research programs at a primary undergraduate institution. The project also recruits underrepresented students and high school students to biochemical research.

This research project uses biophysical techniques to elucidate the enzymatic mechanism of two related enzymes, NADPH oxidase 5 and dual oxidase. Their enzymatic activities are modulated by several factors including domain-domain and protein-protein interactions. These interactions are investigated by ultra-sensitive calorimetry and UV/fluorescence spectroscopy to obtain thermodynamic and kinetic parameters, as well as information about structural changes. In addition, the dissimilarities between their sequences, phosphorylation, and auxiliary protein recognition sites are investigated for their distinct activity profiles. Information from this study provides a molecular understanding of these two enzymes in regards to their catalysis and regulation, defining a new model system for exploring non-phagocyte NADPH Oxidases.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The aim of this research is to elucidate the catalytic and regulatory mechanisms of two calcium-dependent enzymes. The PI and his undergraduate/graduate students studied biomolecular recognition in relation to enzymatic activity by using state-of-the-art instrumentation and performing data analysis to further understand the chemistry underlining biological functions. Specifically, the project participants prepared recombinant proteins and studied molecular interactions to obtain thermodynamic and kinetic parameters that decipher the major driving force for molecular recognition. The grant activities ultimately enhance our fundamental research program in biochemical and biophysical characterization of biomolecules at a primary undergraduate institute.

 Intelligent Merit: Reactive oxygen species (ROS) produced by NOX5 and Duox play important roles in cancers and cardiovascular diseases.  They also exhibit different ROS production and have different primary sequences. Our research revealed that the dissimilarities between their Ca2+ binding, phosphorylation, and auxiliary protein recognition sites are the basis for their distinct activity profiles. During the grant period, the group has obtained information about their structural changes upon Ca2+ binding and how the resulting conformations mediate intramolecular and intermolecular interactions, in which both are crucial to understanding their electron transfer catalysis. By utilizing modeled studies such as spectroscopy, calorimetry, and computational modeling, the group constructed three-dimension protein structures to explain their ROS-producing function. Furthermore, the outcomes are likely translated to provide more insight of other Ca2+ binding proteins and hemeflavoproteins.     

Broad Impacts: The proposal helps develop students’ skills in performing molecular biology, conducting enzymatic assays, and using state-of-the-art instrumentation to obtain a solid comprehension in enzymatic catalysis and regulatory mechanisms; over the course of the project, eight undergraduate and seven M.S. students have received those trainings: two of them are currently pursuing Ph.D. while the others have been successfully employed by pharmaceutical fields. Their research results have also been disseminated through publications and presentations. The grant facilitates the significant development of physical resource— the group implemented two additional characterization techniques (dynamic light scattering and circular dichroism, both in which are instruments acquired through two university internal grants) into the research and has since expanded their research ability into an array of biophysical methods. To integrate research and education at Southern Illinois University Edwardsville, some of the research have been incorporated into biochemistry and biophysical laboratory courses to elicit student learning through research-based experiments.
